title: Summer books of 2021: Science
text:
Helgoland
by Carlo Rovelli, Allen Lane £20

Another brilliant book by Rovelli, who is emerging as the most approachable yet authoritative contemporary writer about quantum physics. He describes a “relational” universe in which there are no absolutes and everything depends on interactions between objects. You won't understand quantum mechanics after reading this — or any other book — but you'll have fun trying.

The Code Breaker: Jennifer Doudna, Gene Editing, and the Future of the Human Race
by Walter Isaacson, Simon & Schuster £30

Isaacson follows up his well received biographies of Leonardo da Vinci, Albert Einstein and Steve Jobs with the contemporary story of Crispr and gene editing — the most significant biomedical advance of the past decade. The heroine of this well-told tale is Nobel laureate Jennifer Doudna, though other scientists who played key roles in the development of Crispr get a look-in too.

The Premonition: A Pandemic Story
by Michael Lewis, Allen Lane £25/WW Norton & Company $30

Lewis, author of Liar's Poker and The Big Short, has another deserved bestseller with The Premonition. This book is only partly about the current pandemic — Covid-19 does not appear till halfway through — but tells the story of a loose-knit band of individuals fighting to overcome appalling failings in the US public health system and improve its response to infectious disease.

The Plague Cycle: The Unending War Between Humanity and Infectious Disease
by Charles Kenny, Simon & Schuster £20

Kenny's sweeping history of human infections shows that there is nothing new about people trying to protect themselves against transmissible diseases through masks, quarantines and social distancing — or in demonising groups believed responsible for spreading illness. The book stands out for its vivid examples and lively writing.

Connections: A Story of Human Feeling
by Karl Deisseroth, Viking £20

Psychiatry professor Deisseroth examines mental illness by interweaving cutting-edge neuroscience with the often moving stories of patients and his personal responses to them. He could not be better qualified for the task, as both a developer of new technology to discover what is happening in the brain and a physician treating people with severe psychological disorders.
